item.title: What Is Acupuncture?
item.description:
Acupuncture is one of the primary treatments under the Traditional Chinese Medicine umbrella, and it has a longer history than herbs. Its first written mention was around 100 BCE, and many scholars believe it was used several centuries earlier.

In Chinese medicine, health depends on the balance of yin and yang, qi (chee) and blood, and the functional harmony of organs and meridians. Imbalance is considered the root of disease.

item.title: Dr. Dan Wang
item.description:
Originally from Northeast China, Dan brings a rich cultural and clinical background rooted in Traditional Chinese Medicine. She earned her degree from the Liaoning University of Traditional Chinese Medicine in the 1990s and has been practicing in the western suburbs of Chicago for the past four years.

Dan is deeply passionate about Chinese medical philosophy and integrates practices such as Taiji, Yijing, and Feng Shui into her holistic approach. She believes true healing comes from achieving balance, both mentally and physically, and she works closely with each patient to support that harmony.

item.title: Does Acupuncture Hurt?
item.description:
Acupuncture needles are hair-thin filiform needles. They are different from the hollow syringes used for injections or blood draws, and insertion is virtually painless for most people.

Points on the hands, feet, and face can occasionally be more sensitive, but this is usually brief.

During treatment, some people feel sensations such as soreness, numbness, bloating, heaviness, warmth, coolness, or even brief itching. These sensations are often temporary.

After needling, most people feel a deep sense of calm and relaxation. This is often when people notice the treatment beginning to work, and when acupuncture starts to heal.

item.title: How Many Sessions Will I Need?
item.description:
The number of sessions depends on your condition and how long you have had it.

In general, the more chronic the issue, the longer the treatment course.

Acupuncture works by restoring balance and supporting your body’s natural healing mechanisms, so it can take time to see clear results.

Typical recommendation is about twice per week for severe pain, or weekly treatment for four to six weeks for many other concerns before judging whether acupuncture is helping.

item.title: What Can Acupuncture Treat?
item.description:
The most common concerns patients visit us for include pain, anxiety, sinus congestion, insomnia, energy improvement, ear problems, digestion issues, fertility, IVF support, postpartum care, and menopause support.

Acupuncture can help reduce pain after injury, but it is wise to see a medical doctor first to rule out fractures and structural damage before beginning acupuncture treatment.

item.title: What Are the Risks of Acupuncture?
item.description:
Licensed acupuncturists receive thorough training in needling techniques and safety, so the risk of serious side effects is very small.

The most common side effects are minor bleeding, mild bruising at the needle site, or occasional dizziness after treatment.

Special caution is needed for people taking blood thinner medication.

Electro-acupuncture may not be suitable for people with pacemakers. Acupuncture without electric stimulation is good enough to help those patients.

item.title: What Is Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)?
item.description:
Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) has a history of thousands of years. It is a summary of long-term experience in fighting disease and an integral part of traditional Chinese culture.

TCM studies human physiology and pathology, along with diagnosis, prevention, and treatment.

Its theoretical system is influenced by Yin-Yang and Five Elements theory, guided by a holistic concept, based on internal organs and meridians, and characterized by syndrome differentiation and treatment.
